questions.question: Which of the following bones forms the posterior pillar of the medial longitudinal arch?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Calcaneum Explanation: Each longitudinal arch has: (a) two pillars, (b) a summit, and (c) joints. Medial Longitudinal Arch The medial longitudinal arch is made up of the calcaneum, talus, navicular, three cuneiform bones, and the medial three metatarsals. a) Pillars: The medial half of the calcaneum forms the posterior pillar of the medial longitudinal arch. The heads of the medial three metatarsals form the anterior pillar of the arch. b) Summit: The talus is located at the highest point (summit) of this arch and acts as its keystone. c) Joints: The main joints involved in the medial longitudinal arch are the talocalcaneonavicular joint and the subtalar joint. Lateral Longitudinal Arch The lateral longitudinal arch is formed by the calcaneum, cuboid, and lateral two metatarsals. It is low and nearly touches the ground, helping to support body weight during walking and running. a) Pillars: The posterior pillar is formed by the lateral tubercle of the calcaneum. The anterior pillar is formed by the heads of the lateral two metatarsals. b) Summit: The summit is at the level of the articular facets on the superior surface of the calcaneum, near the subtalar joint. c) Joints: The main joint is the calcaneocuboid joint. The arch is lower and less flexible than the medial arch, designed to transmit weight and thrust. Reference:

questions.question: Identify X.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Linea semilunaris Explanation: The linea semilunaris is a curved groove that runs from the tip of the 9th costal cartilage to the pubic tubercle. It is located a few centimeters lateral to the midline and corresponds to the outer border of the rectus abdominis muscle. Linea alba (Option B): The linea alba is a tendinous raphe that separates the two rectus muscles. This midline groove divides the anterior abdominal wall into two halves, right and left. Spino-umbilical Line (Option C): Also known as the McBurney’s line, is an imaginary line that extends from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) . The point at the junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd of this line corresponds to the McBurney’s point. The base of the appendix lies deep to this point, and it is commonly used in diagnosing acute appendicitis , as tenderness in this area is a key clinical sign. Addison’s plane (Option D): Also known as the Transpyloric Plane, is an imaginary horizontal plane that passes through the midpoint of the line connecting the suprasternal notch to the pubic symphysis.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a foot drop and weakness in the dorsiflexion of the great toe. He mentions a recent history of a herniated lumbar disc. There is decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot and the first web space between the great toe and the second toe. Which dermatome and root value are most likely involved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) L5 Explanation : Foot Drop indicates weakness in dorsiflexion , primarily controlled by the L5 nerve root through the deep peroneal nerve . The L5 dermatome supplies sensation to the dorsum of the foot and the 1st web space between the great toe and the 2nd toe. The patient's decreased sensation in these areas indicates L5 nerve root involvement. A herniated lumbar disc (most common type—paradiscal), particularly between L4-L5 > L5-S1, can compress the L5 nerve root , leading to the symptoms described. Dermatomes of the lower limb The area of skin supplied by a spinal nerve is termed a dermatome Lower Limb Innervation: Originates from the ventrolateral body wall opposite spinal segments L1–S3 . Primarily innervated by the ventral rami of these segments. Except the superomedial gluteal region is innervated by the dorsal rami of L1–L3 and S1–S3. Limb Bud Orientation: Initially it has preaxial (great toe) and postaxial (little toe) borders. The limb bud rotates medially by 90°, repositioning the great toe medially and the little toe laterally. After rotation, dermatomes are arranged: Preaxial border: L1–L4 (above downward). Postaxial border: S1–S3 (below upward). Region Dermatome Nerve Supply Heel (Skin on the heel) S1 The posterior tibial nerve has two branches Lateral plantar nerve S1 towards the little toe . Medial plantar nerve L5 towards the great toe . The popliteal region, posterior thigh (middle), calf, perineal region S2 Posterior cutaneous nerve Lateral foot, dorsum of the foot (Little toe) S1 (Option B) Sural nerve First web space (Dorsum) L5 (Option A) Deep peroneal nerve Medial aspect of leg (Medial malleolus) L4 (Option C) Saphenous nerve Inguinal region (Proximal lower limb) L1 (Option D) Ilioinguinal nerve, Genitofemoral nerve Anterior thigh L2, L3, L4 (Lateral to medial) Femoral nerve Medial thigh L2, L3, L4 Obturator nerve Perineum S2, S3, S4 Pudendal nerve

questions.question: Identify the muscle/muscle head that is not included in the hamstring group of muscles. A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Explanation: The part marked as “b” in the image is the short head of the biceps femoris, which is not a part of the hamstring group of muscles. (a) Long head of biceps femoris (b) Short head of biceps femoris (c) Semitendinosus (d) Semimembranosus Hamstrings include semitendinosus , semimembranosus, biceps femoris (long head) and ischial head (Hamstring portion) of adductor magnus They are biarticular muscles that cross both the hip and knee joints, integrating hip extension with knee flexion. It is important for movement , and stability , and is commonly tested for injury. The characteristic features of hamstring muscles are: All arise from the ischial tuberosity. All are inserted into one of the bones of the leg. All are supplied by tibial part of the sciatic nerve. All are flexors of the knee and extensors of the hip joint. Semitendinosus (Option C) Semimembranosus (Option D) Biceps Femoris Attachments Ischial tuberosity via common tendon with biceps femoris Inserts on the medial surface of the tibia (pes anserinus) Ischial tuberosity (long, flat tendon) Inserts on medial tibial condyle and forms oblique popliteal ligament Long head (Option A) : Ischial tuberosity (common tendon with semitendinosus) Short head (Option B): From Linea aspera Inserts on head of fibula Relations Posterior to semimembranosus Proximally overlaps popliteal vessels Overlaps popliteal vessels Lies deep to semitendinosus Covered by gluteus maximus Lies superficial; deep to it are semimembranosus, sciatic nerve, adductor magnus Innervation Sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) through tibial division Sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) through tibial division Long head: Sciatic nerve (tibial division) Short head: common peroneal part of Sciatic nerve Actions Flexes knee Extends hip Medial rotation of lower leg Flexes knee Extends hip Medial rotation of lower leg Flexes knee Extends hip Lateral rotation of lower leg Testing Active knee flexion against resistance Active knee flexion against resistance Active knee flexion against resistance Two heads of the biceps femoris (Option D) join together to form a conjoint tendon in the lower third of the thigh that slopes down and laterally and inserts into the head of the fibula.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles is/are supplied by the Nerve to the obturator internus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Gamellus superior and obturator internus Explanation: The nerve to obturator internus innervates both the obturator internus and superior gemellus muscles. It arises from the anterior divisions of the sacral plexus, originating from the L5, S1, and S2 nerve roots. Quadratus femoris and Gamellus inferior are supplied by Nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, 5, S1) Obturator Internus: Attachments Origin: Pelvic surface of the obturator membrane and surrounding bones Insertion: On the medial surface of the greater trochanter Vascular Supply Main supply: gemellar branches of the internal pudendal artery Intrapelvic and extrapelvic parts: branches of the obturator artery Innervation Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2) Actions Laterally rotates the extended thigh. Abducts the flexed thigh. Gemellus Superior and Gamellus Inferior: Gemellus Superior (smaller than G. inferior) Gamellus Inferior Attachments Origin: Arises from the dorsal surface of the ischial spine Blends with the upper border of obturator internus tendon Insertion: Medial surface of the greater trochanter. Origin: Arises from the upper part of the ischial tuberosity Blends with the lower border of obturator internus tendon Insertion: Medial surface of the greater trochanter. Vascular Supply Supplied by internal pudendal artery , inferior gluteal artery, and sometimes superior gluteal artery Mainly by the medial circumflex femoral artery Innervation Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2) Nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1) Actions Assists obturator internus in lateral rotation of the thigh May assist in abduction of the flexed thigh Rotates the extended thigh laterally May contribute to abduction of the flexed thigh Quadratus Femoris: Attachments Origin: Arises from the ischial tuberosity Insertion: Trochanteric crest of the femur Vascular Supply Inferior gluteal artery and medial circumflex femoral artery Innervation Nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1) Actions Produces lateral rotation of the thigh

questions.question: Which among the following structures do not pass through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh Explanation: The posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh only passes through the greater sciatic foramen and not the lesser foramen. Structures passing through greater and lesser sciatic foramen: Greater sciatic notch/foramen/gateway of gluteal region Lesser sciatic notch The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis, fills the foramen almost completely. It is the key muscle of the region. Structures passing above the piriformis are: Superior gluteal nerve Superior gluteal vessels Structures passing below the piriformis are: Inferior gluteal nerve Inferior gluteal vessels Sciatic nerve The posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh Nerve to quadratus femoris Nerve to obturator internus (Option C) Internal pudendal vessels (Option B) Pudendal nerve (Option A) Tendon of obturator internus Pudendal nerve (Option A) Internal pudendal vessels (Option B) Nerve to obturator internus (Option C) The upper and lower parts of the foramen are filled up by the origins of the two gemelli muscles. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 1252. BD Chaurasia Human Anatomy, Volume, 8th edition, Page 85.

questions.question: A 35-year-old athlete presents with difficulty climbing stairs and rising from a seated position. Upon examination, there is weakness in hip extension. Which muscle is most likely affected, and what is the nerve supply?

options.A: Psoas major; Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Gluteus maximus; Inferior gluteal nerve Explanation: Gluteus maximus is the chief extensor of the hip , and weakness would impair actions like rising from a seated position. Its nerve supply is the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2). Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles and their innervation: Action Muscles Nerve supply Flexion Psoas major (chief flexor) (Option A) Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3 Iliacus (chief flexor) Sartorius (Option D) Rectus femoris Pectineus Femoral nerve (L2, L3) Extension Gluteus maximus (chief extensor) (Option B) Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2) Hamstring muscles Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) Abduction Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors) Tensor fasciae latae Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1) (Option C) Adduction Adductor longus Adductor brevis Adductor magnus (chief adductors) Gracilis Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4) Pectineus Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve) Medial rotation Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators) Tensor fasciae latae Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1) Lateral rotation Piriformis Ventral rami of S1, S2 Obturator externus Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4) Obturator internus and Associated gemelli, Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators) Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2) Reference: Vishram Singh textbook of anatomy, 2nd edition, Volume 2, Pages 382, 383

questions.question: In a clinical setting, a physician suspects a weakness in the gluteus maximus muscle. Which of the following functions would not be affected by this?

options.C: Lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh
options.D: Stabilization of pelvis during quiet standing

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Stabilization of pelvis during quiet standing Explanation: The gluteus maximus muscle stabilizes the hip during walking and not during quiet standing. It is one of the major muscles of the gluteal region. Features Largest and most superficial in the gluteal region Broad, thick, and quadrilateral Has an overlying adipose fascia Fascicular architecture with large bundles of fibres separated by fibrous septa Origin Gluteal surface of the ilium behind the posterior gluteal line Outer slope of the dorsal segment of ilium Dorsal surfaces of the sacrum and ilium Sacrotuberous ligament Insertions 3/4th of the muscle into the iliotibial tract 1/4th of the muscle into the gluteal tuberosity Vascular Supply Primarily supplied by the inferior gluteal artery ( ≈ 2/3) Superior gluteal artery Additional supply from the first perforator of profunda femoris and medial circumflex femoral artery Minor branches from lateral circumflex femoral, lateral sacral, and internal pudendal arteries. Innervation Innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2) Actions Extends flexed thigh (Option A) Stabilizes pelvis during gait (vs Option D) Active in raising trunk after stooping (Option B) Active in lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh (Option C) Stabilizes femur via iliotibial tract The gluteus maximus is generally inactive during Quiet standing When swaying forward at the ankle joints When bending forward at the hip joints to touch the toes Testing Tested by hip extension against resistance in prone position with knees flexed

questions.question: A 30-year-old runner complains of difficulty flexing his knee after long-distance running. He reports that once his knee locks in an extended position, it takes effort to initiate flexion again. On examination, you notice that the patient struggles to begin flexion from full extension. Which muscle is likely impaired?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Popliteus Explanation: The popliteus muscle is responsible for unlocking the knee by causing lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during the initial phase of flexion. Impairment of this muscle would make it difficult to initiate flexion from full extension. Action of the knee joint, corresponding muscles and their innervation Action Muscle Innervation Flexion Biceps femoris Semitendinosus Semimembranosus Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) Extension Quadriceps femoris (Option A) Femoral nerve Medial rotation of flexed leg Popliteus Tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1) Semimembranosus Semitendinosus Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) Lateral rotation of flexed leg Biceps femoris (Option C) Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) Locking Vastus medialis (Option D) Femoral nerve Unlocking Popliteus (Option B) Tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1) Locking Unlocking Medial rotation of the femur on the tibia during the terminal phase of extension. Lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during the initial phase of the flexion It is brought about by the quadriceps femoris It is brought about by the popliteus muscle Locked knee becomes rigid Unlocked knee can be further flexed All ligaments are taut All ligaments are relaxed Pathological locking A meniscus tear can cause a knee to lock when a torn piece of cartilage falls off and gets stuck in the knee , or when a large tear folds over and gets stuck. This is called true locking . Pseudo locking is when the knee can't fully extend due to pain or an effusion .

questions.question: The iliotibial tract provides attachment to which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Both B and C Explanation: The deep fascia of the thigh presents two modifications – iliotibial tract and saphenous opening. Iliotibial tract: The iliotibial tract splits into two layers to enclose the tensor fasciae latae and gluteus maximus muscles. Between these muscles, it forms a thickened sheet called the gluteal aponeurosis, which also covers the gluteus medius. The superficial lamina attaches to the tubercle of the iliac crest. The deep lamina attaches to the capsule of the hip joint. Inferiorly, the tract attaches to a smooth area on the anterior surface of the lateral condyle of the tibia. Function : Stabilizes the knee both in extension and in partial flexion. Used during walking and running. When leaning forward with slightly flexed knees, the iliotibial tract supports the knee against gravity, preventing the individual from falling forward. Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume II, 2nd Edition, Page 331

questions.question: Which of the following does not participate in the cruciate anastomosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Deep femoral artery Explanation: Cruciate anastomosis is situated at the upper part of the back of the femur at the level of lesser trochanter. The cruciate anastomosis is formed by the following arteries: Transverse branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery. Transverse branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery. Ascending branch of the first perforating artery. Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery. Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume II, 2nd Edition, Page 370

questions.question: The femoral nerve splits into anterior and posterior divisions, which are separated by which of the following structures?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lateral circumflex femoral artery Explanation: The chief nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh is the femoral nerve. It is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the dorsal divisions of the anterior primary rami of the L2, L3, and L4 nerves. The femoral nerve enters the thigh posterior to the inguinal ligament, just lateral to the femoral sheath. About 2 cm below the inguinal ligament, the femoral nerve divides into anterior and posterior divisions, separated by the lateral circumflex femoral artery. Anterior Division: Gives off two cutaneous branches and one muscular branch: Medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh (cutaneous) Intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh (cutaneous) Muscular branch to the sartorius muscle Posterior Division: Gives off one cutaneous branch and four muscular branches: Saphenous nerve (cutaneous) Muscular branches supplying the quadriceps femoris. Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume II, 2nd Edition, Page 340

questions.question: Which two nerves provide the dual innervation of the pectineus muscle?

options.C: Medial Pectoral Nerve and Lateral Pectoral Nerve

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Obturator Nerve and Femoral Nerve Explanation: The Pectenius muscle is a composite/hybrid muscle that is innervated by both the obturator and femoral nerve. Hybrid muscles Composite or hybrid muscles contain multiple fiber types that perform the same function and are innervated by different nerves for each fiber set. Muscle Innervation Pectoralis Major (Option C) Sternocostal Head Medial Pectoral Nerve (C8, T1) Clavicular Head Lateral Pectoral Nerve (C5, 6, 7) Subscapularis Upper & Lower Subscapular Nerves (C5, 6) Brachialis (Option D) Musculocutaneous Nerve (C5, 6, 7) (medial) Radial Nerve (C5, 6, 7, 8, T1) (lateral) Flexor Digitorum Profundus Lateral Part Anterior Interosseous Branch of Median Nerve (C8, T1) Medial Part Ulnar Nerve (C8, T1) Pectineus (Option A) Obturator Nerve (L2, 3, 4) Femoral Nerve (L2, 3, 4) Adductor Magnus Adductor Part Posterior Division of Obturator Nerve (L2, 3, 4) Hamstring Part Tibial Branch of Sciatic Nerve (L4, 5, S1) Biceps Femoris Long Head Tibial Branch of Sciatic Nerve (L4, 5, S1) Short Head Common Peroneal Division of Sciatic Nerve (L4, 5, S1) Digastric muscle Anterior belly Nerve to mylohyoid Posterior belly Facial nerve Reference: https://orthopaedicprinciples.com/2021/03/muscles-with-dual-innervation/

questions.question: Which of the following regarding the marked structure is true?

options.A: Nerve to obturator internus passes above it
options.B: Innervated by L5, S1 nerve roots
options.D: It is a medial rotator of the hip joint

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pudendal nerve passes below it Explanation: The structure marked here is the Piriformis muscle, and the Pudendal nerve passes inferior to it. Piriformis: Attachments Origin : Anterior surface of sacrum (3 digitations) Gluteal surface of ilium near posterior inferior iliac spine Capsule of sacroiliac joint Insertion: Medial side of the upper border of the greater trochanter of the femur The piriformis muscle emerges from the pelvis, almost filling the greater sciatic foramen completely and is the key muscle of the area. Structures running superior to piriformis Superior gluteal nerve and vessel (Option A) Structures running inferior to piriformis. Inferior gluteal nerve and vessels Greater trochanter Sciatic nerve Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh Nerve to quadratus femoris Nerve to obturator internus Internal pudendal vessels Pudendal nerve (Option C) Vascular Supply Main supply: Superior gluteal artery Contributions: Gemellar branches of internal pudendal, inferior gluteal artery, lateral sacral artery Innervation Innervated by superior gluteal nerve and ventral rami of S1 and S2 (Option B) Actions Laterally rotates extended thigh (Option D) Abducts flexed thigh Testing No isolated

questions.question: A 30-year-old male is being examined for abnormal gait. His Trendelenberg sign is positive. What is false about testing for the Trendelenburg sign?

options.A: The side of the hip that droops down is the unaffected side
options.B: The gluteus medius and minimus muscles are affected
options.C: The patients have a characteristic lurching gait
options.D: The uncompensated Trendelenburg sign is elicited with a walking patient

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The uncompensated Trendelenburg sign is elicited with a walking patient the compensated is elicited in a walking patient. Tensor Fasciae Latae Gluteus Medius Gluteus Minimus Attachments Origin : Outer lip of the iliac crest extending from the anterior superior iliac spine to the tubercle of the crest. Insertion : Iliotibial tract 3–5 cm below the level of the greater trochanter. Origin: Gluteal surface of the ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines Insertion: Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. Origin: Gluteal surfaces of the ilium between anterior & inferior gluteal lines. Insertion: Anterior aspect of the Greater trochanter Relations Between gluteus medius and sartorius Covered by fascia lata Covered by gluteus maximus (posterior third) Deep to gluteus minimus Deep to gluteus medius Related to hip joint capsule Vascular Supply Mainly from lateral circumflex femoral artery Supplied by superior gluteal artery Deep branch of superior gluteal artery Trochanteric anastomosis Main trunk and deep branch of superior gluteal arter y Trochanteric anastomosis Innervation Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) Actions Hip flexor and abductor Stabilizes pelvis Helps maintain extended knee Abducts thigh Medial & lateral rotation of thigh Supports pelvis during single-leg stance Abducts thigh Medial and lateral rotation of thigh Testing Depression below anterior superior iliac spine Abduction against resistance Medial rotation against resistance Abduction against resistance Medial rotation against resistance Abduction against resistance Trendelenberg sign: When the body's weight is balanced on one leg, the gluteal muscles on the supported side help elevate the opposite, unsupported side of the pelvis. However, if there is a malfunction in the abductor mechanism, the Sound side sinks (Option A) , which is referred to as a positive Trendelenburg sign (uncompensated). This sign indicates issues with hip abductors, such as paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus (Option B) ; problems with the fulcrum, including congenital or pathological hip dislocations; and concerns related to body weight, such as an unhealed fracture of the femoral neck. When patients with the gluteus medius and minimus paralysis walk, they have a characteristic lurching gait (Option C) ie, during the single leg supporting phase of walking, there is leaning of the trunk to the affected side known as the compensated Trendelenburg sign . Duck waddling gait is seen when both the sides are affected.

questions.question: A patient reports pain and decreased sensation along the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg, extending onto the lateral side of the foot, following an ankle sprain. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sural nerve Explanation: The sural nerve innervates the posterolateral aspect of the leg . Injury can occur due to ankle sprains , fractures, or tight footwear, leading to pain and sensory loss in this region. Cutaneous Innervation of Lower Limb: Primarily from the lumbar and sacral plexuses. Except some proximal uni segmental nerves arise from T12 or L1 spinal nerves. Thigh Innervation: Main supply: Lateral and Posterior Cutaneous Nerves of the Thigh and Cutaneous Branch of Femoral Nerve. Leg Innervation: Anteromedial Aspect: Saphenous nerve (Option B) Posterolateral Aspect: Sural nerve Anterolateral Aspect: Superficial peroneal nerve (Option C) Foot Innervation: Dorsum of the Foot: Mainly by superficial peroneal nerves. Sole of the Foot: Supplied by cutaneous branches of medial and lateral plantar nerves. Nerve Injury Risks: Iliohypogastric, Ilioinguinal, and Genitofemoral Nerve Injury: Common during lower abdomen or spine surgeries. Can result in anesthesia, hyperesthesia, neuralgia or causalgia in their sensory distribution. Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve Injury: (Option D) Vulnerable to entrapment beneath the inguinal ligament near the anterior superior iliac spine. Causes paresthesia or dysaesthesia (meralgia paresthetica) on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh, intensified by walking or hip extension. Sural Nerve Injury: (Option A) Occur at the level of the ankle due to fractures or sprain, tight shoes, or surgery. Cause pain and diminished sensation along the postero-lateral lower leg extending onto the lateral surface of the ankle and foot.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man is involved in a car accident and sustains a fracture to the ischial tuberosity. He now presents with weakness in knee flexion and hip extension, with intact sensation. Which muscle group and nerve are likely involved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hamstrings; sciatic nerve Explanation : The hamstrings , innervated by the sciatic nerve , are responsible for knee flexion and hip extension. A fracture of the ischial tuberosity can affect the attachment site of these muscles. Sciatic nerve Size and Origin: Thickest nerve in the body (1.5 to 2 cm wide). Arises from the sacral plexus in the pelvis. Components: Tibial Part : Formed by ventral divisions of anterior primary rami (L4, L5, S1, S2, S3). Common Peroneal Part : Formed by dorsal divisions of anterior primary rami (L4, L5, S1, S2). Course: Begins in the pelvis, in front of the piriformis muscle. Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis. Divides into tibial and common peroneal nerves at the superior angle of the popliteal fossa. Relations: Deep Relations: Ischium, tendon of obturator internus, quadratus femoris, adductor magnus. Superficial Relations : Gluteus maximus (in the gluteal region) and long head of biceps femoris (in the thigh). Branches: Articular branches to the hip joint (gluteal region) . Muscular branches (Option B) The tibial part supplies the semitendinosus, the semimembranosus, the long head of the biceps femoris, and the ischial head of the adductor magnus (medial side) The common peroneal part supplies only a short head of biceps femoris (lateral side). Clinical Correlation: Compression against the femur can cause "sleeping foot," resulting in lower limb paresthesia when sitting for long periods. Quadriceps; femoral nerve (Option A) : Quadriceps extend the knee, not flex it. Adductors; obturator nerve (Option C) : Adductors handle hip adduction, not knee flexion or hip extension. Gluteal muscles; superior gluteal nerve (Option D) : Gluteal muscles control hip abduction, not knee flexion or hip extension.

questions.question: Identify the marked structures in the given image:

options.A: a) Semitendinosus, b) Biceps femoris, c) Popliteal artery, d) Tibial nerve
options.B: a) Semitendinosus, b) Biceps femoris, c) Tibial nerve, d) Popliteal artery
options.C: a) Biceps femoris, b) Semitendinosus, c) Popliteal artery, d) Tibial nerve
options.D: a) Biceps femoris, b) Semitendinosus, c) Tibial nerve, d) Popliteal artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) a) Biceps femoris, b)Semitendinosus, c)Tibial nerve, d) Popliteal artery Biceps femoris The Superomedial boundary is formed by b) the Semitendinosus M arked structure c) is Tibial nerve and d) is Popliteal artery because in the upper part of the fossa, nerve is lateral and the artery is medial. Popliteal fossa The popliteal fossa is a diamond-shaped hollow at the back of the knee, becoming prominent when flexed, and serves as a passage for major vessels and nerves between the thigh and leg. Boundaries Superomedial : Semitendinosus and Semimembranosus Superolateral: Biceps Femoris Inferomedial: Medial head of Gastrocnemius Inferolateral: Lateral head of Gastrocnemius and Plantaris Floor (anterior wall): Formed by the popliteal surface of the femur, knee joint capsule, oblique popliteal ligament, and popliteal fascia covering the popliteus muscle. Roof (posterior wall): Formed by the popliteal fascia, containing the short saphenous vein and three cutaneous nerves (posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh, medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh, sural communicating nerve). All structures pierce the roof except the medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Contents Main Contents: Popliteal artery and branches Popliteal vein and tributaries Tibial nerve and branches Common peroneal nerve and branches Popliteal lymph nodes Popliteal fat pad Additional Structures: Posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh (terminal part) Descending genicular branch of obturator nerve Terminal part of the short saphenous vein Arrangement of Key Structures (NVA/AVN pattern) Upper part: Nerve, Vein, Artery (lateral to medial) Middle part: Nerve, Vein, Artery (superficial to deep) Lower part: Artery, Vein, Nerve (lateral to medial)

questions.question: Which of the following sets of muscles is referred to as "guy rope" muscles that stabilise the bony pelvis on the femur?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sartorius, Gracilis, Semitendinosus Explanation: The term "guy rope muscles" refers to the Sartorius, Gracilis, and Semitendinosus muscles, which each originate from different compartments of the thigh—anterior, medial, and posterior, respectively. These muscles play a crucial role in stabilizing the pelvis on the femur. Guy rope muscles 1. Sartorius 2. Gracilis 3. Semitendinosus Compartment Part of the anterior compartment Part of the medial compartment Part of the posterior compartment Innervation Femoral nerve Obturator nerve Sciatic nerve Action Hip flexion, abduction, and external rotation Hip adduction and knee flexion Knee flexion and hip extension Origin Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) Inferior pubic ramus Ischial tuberosity Insertion Upper part of the medial surface of the tibia . ( Pes anserinus or Goosefoot tendon is the broad, conjoined tendon formed by these 3 muscles, inserting on the medial surface of the proximal tibia) Together, these muscles anchor below at the tibia, spreading out above to support the pelvic structure, functioning effectively like "guy ropes" to maintain stability. Bursa Anserinus , situated on the upper medial surface of the tibia, separates the tendons of the Sartorius, Gracilis, and Semitendinosus muscles at their insertion points and also isolates them from the tibial collateral ligament.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with difficulty in adducting his thigh after sustaining an injury during a soccer match. Upon examination, weakness in adduction and medial rotation of the thigh is noted. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for these actions, and what is its nerve supply?

options.D: Adductor part of adductor magnus; Obturator nerve (posterior division)

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Adductor part of adductor magnus; Obturator nerve (posterior division) medial rotation. It is innervated by the obturator nerve, specifically the posterior division. The weakness observed in these actions following the injury indicates the involvement of adductor magnus. Muscles of the medial (adductor) compartment of the thigh: Muscle Origin Insertion Nerve Supply Actions Pectineus (Option A) Pecten pubis Superior ramus of the pubis Line extending from the lesser trochanter to the linea aspera Femoral nerve and obturator nerve Adduction of the thigh Flexion of thigh Gracilis (Option B) Body of the pubis and ischiopubic ramus Upper part of the medial surface of tibia Obturator nerve Adduction of thigh Flexion and medial rotation of leg Adductor longus (Option C) Body of the pubis Middle 1/3rd of linea aspera Obturator nerve Adduction and medial rotation of thigh Adductor brevis Body and inferior ramus of the pubis Pectineal lines and proximal part of linea aspera Obturator nerve Adduction of thigh Adductor magnus (largest muscle of this compartment) (Option D) Hamstring part: inferolateral part of the ischial tuberosity Adductor part: outer part of the ischiopubic ramus Adductor part: Medial margin of gluteal tuberosity , linea aspera, medial supracondylar line Hamstring part: Adductor tubercle Adductor part: By the obturator nerve Hamstring part : By the tibial part of sciatic nerve Adduction and medial rotation of thigh Weak extension of hip joint

questions.question: Which of the following is not the action of the marked structure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Extension of knee Explanation: The marked structure is Sartorius . It is responsible for flexing the thigh at the hip, flexing the knee , and aiding in the lateral rotation of the thigh . However, it does not perform knee extension; rather, it assists in knee flexion when the leg is raised. Muscles of the front of the thigh: Muscle Nerve Supply Actions 1. Quadriceps femoris (a) Rectus femoris Femoral nerve Flexion of the hip joint and extension of the knee joint (b) Vastus lateralis Femoral nerve Extension of the knee joint (c) Vastus medialis Femoral nerve Extension of the knee joint (d) Vastus intermedius Femoral nerve Extension of the knee joint 2. Articularis genu Femoral nerve Pulls up the synovial membrane of the knee joint during its extension 3. Sartorius Femoral nerve Hip: Flexion, abduction and lateral rotation Knee: Flexion, medial rotation Leg: Flexion (Options A, B, D) 4. Tensor fasciae latae Superior gluteal nerve (different from the rest) Abduction of the hip joint

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with leg pain and weakness after a heavy deadlift. He reports heaviness in his feet, difficulty standing on his toes, and performing calf raises. Neurological examination reveals weakness in plantar flexion, inability to flex his toes and diminished ankle reflexes. Which spinal cord segments are primarily involved in this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) S1, S2 Explanation: The weakness in plantar flexion and difficulty in flexing the toes i ndicate involvement of the muscles innervated by the S1 and S2 spinal segments, primarily the gastrocnemius and soleus . Segmental innervation of muscles of the lower limb: Segments Muscles innervated L1 Psoas major L2, L3 (Option C) Gracilis, pectineus, sartorius L3, L4 (Option D) Quadriceps femoris, adductors of the thigh L4, L5 (Option A) Tensor fasciae latae, tibialis anterior, tibialis posterior L5, S1 Gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, semitendinosus, semimembranosus S1, S2 (Option B) Gluteus maximus, biceps femoris, gastrocnemius , soleus . S2, S3 Flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, interossei Segmental innervation of joints of lower limb Joints Movements Hip joint Flexion, adduction, and medial rotation (L2, L3) Extension, abduction, and lateral rotation (L4, L5) Knee joint Extension (L3, L4) Flexion (L5; S1) Ankle joint Dorsiflexion (L4, L5) Plantar flexion (S1, S2) Foot Invertors (L4, L5) Evertors (L5, S1) Reference: Vishram Singh textbook of anatomy, 2nd Edition, Pages 475, 476

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a foot drop following a recent knee injury. Which of the following nerves, part of the sacral plexus, is most likely injured, leading to the inability to dorsiflex the foot?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Common peroneal nerve Explanation: Common peroneal nerve branches from the sciatic nerve and innervates the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot (e.g., tibialis anterior is supplied by deep peroneal nerve, which is a branch of common peroneal nerve). Injury to this nerve often results in foot drop. Sacral Plexus: The sacral plexus is a complex network of nerves formed by the anterior rami (ventral rami) of the L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3 spinal nerves, with some contributions from S4. It is located on the posterior wall of the pelvis, resting on the anterior surface of the piriformis muscle. The sacral plexus plays a critical role in providing motor and sensory innervation to parts of the pelvis, perineum, and lower limbs. Root Values and Divisions Root Values: L4 to S4 contribute to the sacral plexus. Divisions: Anterior Division: Primarily supplies muscles involved in flexion and related functions. Posterior Division: Supplies muscles associated with extension and related movements. Major Nerves of the Sacral Plexus Nerve Formation Pathway Functions Sciatic Nerve The largest nerve in the body, derived from both anterior and posterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, passing beneath the piriformis muscle, and travels down the posterior thigh. Supplies the posterior thigh muscles. It divides into two key branches: Tibial Nerve (Anterior Division) (Option B): Innervates the posterior leg and foot muscles. Common Peroneal Nerve (Posterior Division): Innervates muscles of the lateral and anterior leg. Clinical Note : Injury to the common peroneal nerve can result in foot drop, a condition characterized by difficulty lifting the front part of the foot. Pudendal Nerve (Option D) Arises from the anterior divisions of S2, S3, and S4. Travels out of the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen and into the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen. Provides motor and sensory innervation to the perineum, including muscles of the pelvic floor and external genitalia. It is crucial for maintaining continence and sexual function. Superior Gluteal Nerve Originates from the posterior divisions of L4, L5, and S1. Exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, superior to the piriformis muscle. Innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae, which are responsible for hip abduction and pelvis stabilization during walking. Inferior Gluteal Nerve Originates from the posterior divisions of L5, S1, and S2. Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis. Innervates the gluteus maximus, the primary extensor of the hip joint. Posterior Femoral Cutaneous Nerve (Option A) Arises from the anterior and posterior divisions of S1, S2, and S3. Travels alongside the sciatic nerve, exiting the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen. Provides sensory innervation to the skin on the posterior thigh and lower buttocks. Minor Nerves of the Sacral Plexus Nerve to Piriformis (S1, S2) : Supplies the piriformis muscle, which assists in lateral rotation of the hip. Nerve to Quadratus Femoris (L4, L5, S1) : Innervates the quadratus femoris and inferior gemellus muscles, responsible for lateral hip rotation and stabilization. Nerve to Obturator Internus (L5, S1, S2): Innervates the obturator internus and superior gemellus muscles, involved in lateral rotation of the thigh. Lumbosacral Trunk The lumbosacral trunk, formed by the

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of tingling and numbness in the outer aspect of his right thigh. He reports that the symptoms worsen when he sits for prolonged periods and improves when he stands or walks. Upon examination, there is a sensory deficit in the lateral thigh region. Which nerve root value is primarily involved in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) L2 and L3 Explanation: Based on the clinical scenario, the patient's symptoms align with meralgia paresthetica, marked by tingling and numbness in the outer thigh that worsens with prolonged sitting and improves with standing or walking. This condition results from compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, which is primarily derived from the dorsal divisions of the L2 and L3 nerve roots. Lumbar Plexus: The lumbar plexus is a network of nerves formed by the anterior rami (ventral rami) of the lumbar spinal nerves, specifically L1 to L4. It is located within the psoas major muscle in the posterior abdominal wall. The lumbar plexus is responsible for providing motor and sensory innervation to the pelvic region and the lower limb. Division of Roots The roots of the lumbar plexus can be categorised into two main divisions: Anterior Division: Comprising roots that generally supply flexor muscles and associated sensory areas. Posterior Division: Comprising roots that typically supply extensor muscles and their corresponding sensory territories. Major Nerves of the Lumbar Plexus Nerve Formation Pathway Functions Obturator Nerve Formed from the ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4. It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen. Innervates the muscles of the medial thigh (adductors) and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the medial thigh. Femoral Nerve Formed from the dorsal divisions of L2, L3, and L4. (Option C) It passes under the inguinal ligament into the anterior compartment of the thigh. Supplies the muscles of the anterior thigh (such as quadriceps) and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and part of the medial leg. Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve Formed from the dorsal divisions of L2 and L3. It courses laterally across the iliacus muscle and under the inguinal ligament. Provides purely sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral aspect of the thigh. This nerve is particularly important in conditions such as meralgia paresthetica, where it can become compressed, leading to tingling and pain in the outer thigh. Most commonly injured during Mc Roberts manure & Laproscopic hernia surgery. Proximal Nerves: Iliohypogastric Nerve (L1) Function: Supplies the skin over the lower abdomen and contributes to abdominal muscle innervation. Most common nerve entrapped in open inguinal hernia surgery, leads to the common cause of pain syndrome. Ilioinguinal Nerve (L1) Function: Provides sensory innervation to the skin of the groin, part of the thigh, root of the penis, clitoris, and anterior I of the scrotum. Genitofemoral Nerve (L1, L2) (Option A) Branches: Genital Branch: Supplies the cremaster muscle and the skin of the scrotum in males, and the labia majora in females. Efferent for cremasteric reflex. It is injured in open hernia repair. Femoral Branch: Supplies the skin of the upper anterior thigh. Afferent for cremasteric reflex. It is anesthetized in femoral vein catheterization. Lumbosacral Trunk (L4, L5) (Option D) Function: Contributes to the formation of the sacral plexus, which innervates the lower limb.
